Habitat/Location: Central and South America
Extra Info: Wings have bold '88' pattern on underside

Extra Info: White wings with red and black eye spots

Extra Info: Pink and yellow patterns mimicking flowers

Habitat/Location: Southeastern USA and Caribbean
Extra Info: Black wings with blue spots and red abdomen

Habitat/Location: Southeast Asia
Extra Info: One of the largest moths with snake-head wing tips

Habitat/Location: Central and South America
Extra Info: Bright orange wings with black bands

Habitat/Location: Central America and Mexico
Extra Info: Brown wings with white and orange bands

Habitat/Location: North America
Extra Info: Black and orange striped wings

Habitat/Location: North America
Extra Info: White wings with dark markings near tips

Habitat/Location: Europe and Asia
Extra Info: White wings with rows of black dots

Habitat/Location: Europe
Extra Info: Dark brown wings with orange spots and tails

Habitat/Location: Central and South America
Extra Info: Iridescent blue wings with brown underside

Habitat/Location: South and Southeast Asia
Extra Info: Dark wings with blue-white spots

Habitat/Location: Australia and New Guinea
Extra Info: Large butterfly with green and black wings

Habitat/Location: Europe and Asia
Extra Info: Brown wings with orange spots

Habitat/Location: Central and South America
Extra Info: Brown wings with white and orange bands

Extra Info: White wings with black spots

Habitat/Location: Northeastern Australia
Extra Info: Large green, black, and yellow butterfly

Habitat/Location: Europe
Extra Info: Silvery-blue males and brown females

Habitat/Location: Europe and Asia
Extra Info: Golden-brown wings with pale square spots

Extra Info: Reddish-brown wings with dark markings

Extra Info: Black and red wings; larvae are yellow-black striped

Habitat/Location: Europe, Asia, North America
Extra Info: Transparent wings mimicking wasps

Habitat/Location: Southern Europe and North Africa
Extra Info: Yellow wings with orange patch in males

Habitat/Location: Western North America
Extra Info: White wings with red/black spots

Habitat/Location: North America
Extra Info: Yellow wings with dark borders

Habitat/Location: Chalk grasslands
Extra Info: Bright blue wings with black and white edges

Habitat/Location: Rainforests
Extra Info: Very large wings and elongated shape

Habitat/Location: Woodlands and fields
Extra Info: Distinct snout-like palps and orange-brown wings

Habitat/Location: Rainforests
Extra Info: Long tail streamers and yellow patterned wings

Habitat/Location: Forest edges
Extra Info: Dark brown wings with a white band

Habitat/Location: Meadows and open woodlands
Extra Info: Brown wings with eye spots for predator distraction

Habitat/Location: Tropical Southeast Asia
Extra Info: Bright copper-colored tail and striking wing patterns

Habitat/Location: Meadows and open fields
Extra Info: Orange-and-black patterned wings with scalloped edges

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical regions, open woodlands, gardens, and forest edges
Extra Info: Active during the day; often seen basking and feeding on flower nectar

Habitat/Location: Found in Asia, Africa, and Australia; common in India in gardens, open fields, and grasslands
Extra Info: Female mimics Plain Tiger (Batesian mimicry); male is black with white patches; caterpillars feed on Acanthaceae and Portulacaceae plants

Habitat/Location: Found in North America — especially in wooded areas, forest edges, and along streams; also seen in gardens during summer
Extra Info: Named for the small comma-shaped silver mark on the underside of its hind wings; has ragged wing edges that help it blend with dead leaves; adults hibernate during winter in tree bark or leaf litter

Habitat/Location: Found in western and central North America — prefers open grassy fields, prairies, and foothills; often near host plants of the mustard family
Extra Info: Has distinctive white wings with greenish marbling on the underside; adults are active in spring; larvae feed on wild mustard plants (Brassicaceae family); plays a key role in pollination of spring flowers.

Habitat/Location: Found in eastern North America — prefers pine forests, dry sandy areas, and open woodlands where pine trees grow; especially common near pitch pine and jack pine stands
Extra Info: Small brownish butterfly with a faint reddish line across the hindwings; adults appear only once a year in spring; caterpillars feed mainly on pine needles; well-camouflaged to blend with bark and pine cones.

Exotic or Not: Not exotic (found in Asia, fairly common in its range)
Habitat/Location: Found in South and Southeast Asia, including India, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, and Thailand; prefers forest edges, scrublands, and gardens
Extra Info: Small black-and-white butterfly with distinctive elbowed patterns on the wings; larvae feed on host plants like Zizyphus species; known for rapid, jerky flight patterns.

Habitat/Location: Found in eastern and southern Australia; commonly in eucalyptus forests, woodlands, and suburban gardens
Extra Info: One of the largest moths in Australia with wingspans up to 12 cm; larvae feed on eucalyptus leaves; adults do not feed and rely on stored energy; striking eye spots on wings help deter predators.

Exotic or Not: Exotic (native to Europe and North America)
Habitat/Location: Found in Europe, North America, and parts of Asia; prefers gardens, meadows, grasslands, and open woodlands
Extra Info: Known for bright orange hindwings with black spots and brown forewings with white patterns; caterpillars are called woolly bears; adults are nocturnal and use aposematic coloration to warn predators of toxicity.

Habitat/Location: Found in eastern and southern North America; prefers woodlands, gardens, fields, and areas with abundant vegetation
Extra Info: Large white moth with black leopard-like spots; caterpillars are called woolly bears and are black with orange bands; adults are nocturnal and do not feed; striking wing patterns serve as a predator deterrent.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests of Sub-Saharan Africa
Extra Info: Males have brilliant blue iridescent wings with darker edges; females are paler. Found in forest edges and feed on mistletoe plants. Belongs to the Lycaenidae (blue butterflies) family.

Scientific Name: Heliconius hecale (commonly called the Gold-Banded Heliconian)
Habitat/Location: Found in Central and South America — tropical forests and gardens
Extra Info: Recognized by its black wings with striking golden or yellow bands; known for slow, graceful flight. Feeds on passionflower plants and plays an important role in pollination.

Habitat/Location: Found across South and Southeast Asia, Australia, and the Pacific islands; prefers gardens, forests, and open sunny areas
Extra Info: Males are black with striking white and purple-blue spots, while females are brown with orange markings. Known for its strong territorial behavior — males often chase away rivals.

Habitat/Location: Found in South and Southeast Asia — India, Malaysia, Indonesia; inhabits tropical rainforests
Extra Info: A member of the swallowtail family (Papilionidae). Has striking bluish-green bands on black wings. Fast and strong flier often seen near forest streams.

Habitat/Location: Found in Central and South America — mainly Mexico to Ecuador; inhabits tropical rainforests
Extra Info: A large black butterfly with brilliant green patches on the forewings and red spots on the hindwings. Males have brighter colors. It belongs to the swallowtail family (Papilionidae) and is known for its graceful flight near forest edges.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (common in Europe and Asia)
Habitat/Location: Found across Europe, North Africa, and temperate Asia — prefers scrublands, grasslands, and forest clearings
Extra Info: Small butterfly with bright green underwings and brown upperwings (usually kept closed). Known for its excellent camouflage in green vegetation. Belongs to the Lycaenidae family.

Habitat/Location: Found throughout North and Central America — in open fields, gardens, meadows, and forest edges
Extra Info: Small gray butterfly with orange spots near the tail and thin white and black lines across wings. Its caterpillars feed on many plants, making it highly adaptable. Known for its “false head” tail tips that confuse predators.

Habitat/Location: Found in northern Australia and New Guinea — tropical rainforests
Extra Info: One of the largest moths on Earth, with a wingspan up to 27 cm (10.6 inches). Males have long tails on their hindwings. Adults do not eat; they live only to mate and lay eggs. The caterpillars feed on rainforest trees.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (common in Europe, Asia, North Africa)
Habitat/Location: Found in Europe, Asia, and North Africa — open fields, gardens, and meadows
Extra Info: Resembles a hummingbird in flight; hovers while feeding on nectar with a long proboscis. Active during the day unlike most moths. Migratory species, known for rapid and agile flying.

Habitat/Location: Found in western North America — mountainous regions, meadows, and open forest
Extra Info: Belongs to the swallowtail family (Papilionidae). Males have striking black wings with pale yellow markings; females are slightly larger. Known for strong flight and visiting a variety of nectar plants.

Habitat/Location: Found throughout the United States, southeastern Canada, and parts of Central America — forests, fields, and gardens
Extra Info: Bright yellow wings with large eye spots on hindwings to scare predators. Males have brownish forewings, females slightly larger. Caterpillars are known to have stinging spines. Belongs to the Saturniidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not exotic (native to Central and South America)
Habitat/Location: Central and South American forests, 0–1,200 m altitude.
Extra Info: White-marked wings; adults feed on overripe fruits and nectar; larvae feed on trees like Calycophyllum and Uncaria.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests, gardens, and open areas in Central and South America
Extra Info: Bright orange wings with black markings; fast flier; adults feed on nectar and rotting fruit; popular in butterfly gardens.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (found in Europe and parts of Asia)
Habitat/Location: Open meadows, grasslands, and rocky hills
Extra Info: White wings with greenish or marbled patterns on the underside; feeds on nectar; belongs to the Pieridae family.

Habitat/Location: Deciduous forests across eastern North America
Extra Info: Pale green wings with long tails on hindwings; adults do not eat; caterpillars feed on hickory, walnut, and sweetgum trees; belongs to the Saturniidae family.

Habitat/Location: Rainforests of Madagascar
Extra Info: Iridescent multicolored wings; day-flying moth; often mistaken for a butterfly; feeds on nectar as an adult; caterpillars feed on Omphalea plants.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests, gardens, and open areas in Central and South America
Extra Info: Bright green and black patterned wings; adults feed on nectar and rotting fruit; fast and strong flier; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Mangroves, coastal areas, and open woodlands in the southeastern United States, Central and South America
Extra Info: Small brown wings with white spots; rapid, darting flight; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on mangrove plants; belongs to the Hesperiidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests, woodland edges, and gardens in Central and South America
Extra Info: Brownish-orange wings with white and black markings; adults feed on nectar; known for their gliding flight; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests in Central and South America
Extra Info: Small butterflies with metallic-looking spots or streaks on their wings; adults feed on nectar; caterpillars feed on various host plants; belongs to the Riodinidae family.

Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, gardens, and forest edges across North America.
Extra Info: Orange wings with black and blue spots; adults feed on nectar and rotting fruit; hibernates as adults during winter; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, gardens, and forests across North America; migrates to Mexico in winter
Extra Info: Bright orange wings with black veins; famous for long-distance migration; larvae feed on milkweed; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to North America, Europe, and Asia)
Habitat/Location: Forests, woodlands, parks, and gardens across temperate regions of North America and Eurasia
Extra Info: Dark brown wings with pale yellow edges and blue spots; hibernates as an adult during winter; adults feed on tree sap and rotting fruit; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Found in Africa, Asia, and parts of Europe — gardens, open woodlands, and areas with oleander plants
Extra Info: Large green and pink wings; adults feed on nectar; caterpillars feed on oleander and other Apocynaceae plants; belongs to the Sphingidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests in India, Southeast Asia, and Myanmar
Extra Info: Upper wings bright orange with black and blue markings; underwings mimic dead leaves for camouflage; adults feed on rotting fruits and tree sap; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (common in Europe and Asia)
Habitat/Location: Meadows, grasslands, woodland edges, and gardens across Europe and temperate Asia
Extra Info: Males have bright orange tips on forewings; females are mostly white with black spots; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on cruciferous plants; belongs to the Pieridae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to Australia and nearby islands)
Habitat/Location: Forest edges, woodlands, orchards, and gardens in Australia
Extra Info: Black wings with white and yellow markings; strong and fast flier; caterpillars feed on citrus and other Rutaceae plants; belongs to the Papilionidae family.

Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, gardens, and roadsides across most of the world
Extra Info: Orange-brown wings with black and white markings; migratory species; adults feed on nectar; caterpillars feed on thistles and mallows; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Southeast Asian forests, mangroves, and gardens — mainly in the Philippines, Malaysia, and Taiwan
Extra Info: Large white wings with black veins; slow, graceful flight; adults feed on nectar and often seen gliding in butterfly conservatories; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to Europe and temperate Asia)
Habitat/Location: Gardens, parks, meadows, and woodland edges across Europe and temperate Asia
Extra Info: Reddish-brown wings with large eye spots on hindwings; adults feed on nectar and tree sap; hibernates in winter; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Coniferous forests and pine woodlands in western North America
Extra Info: White wings with subtle black markings; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on pine needles; belongs to the Pieridae family.

Habitat/Location: Woodlands, fields, gardens, and wetlands across North America
Extra Info: Iridescent blue hindwings with black forewings; larvae feed on pipevine plants making them toxic to predators; strong and fast flier; belongs to the Papilionidae family.

Habitat/Location: Deciduous forests, woodlands, and suburban areas across North America
Extra Info: Large brown wings with prominent eyespots on hindwings; adults do not eat; caterpillars feed on a variety of trees including oak, maple, and birch; belongs to the Saturniidae family

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests in South and Southeast Asia — India, Nepal, Bhutan, and Myanmar
Extra Info: Black wings with bright blue and white markings; adults feed on nectar and rotting fruit; known for strong flight; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Oak woodlands and forests across Europe
Extra Info: Upper wings purple in males, brown in females; underwings brown with orange crescents; adults feed on honeydew and nectar; larvae feed on oak leaves; belongs to the Lycaenidae family.

Habitat/Location: Meadows, grasslands, and open woodlands in North America
Extra Info: Bright copper-orange wings with purplish sheen; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on sorrel and dock plants; belongs to the Lycaenidae family.

Habitat/Location: Woodlands, forests, gardens, and fields across North America
Extra Info: Orange-brown wings with dark spots and a silver “?” mark on the underside of hindwings; adults feed on nectar, tree sap, and rotting fruit; hibernates as an adult; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to North America, Europe, Asia, and North Africa)
Habitat/Location: Gardens, parks, forests, meadows, and urban areas across temperate regions
Extra Info: Black wings with red bands and white spots; adults feed on nectar and overripe fruit; migratory in some regions; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests in Central and South America
Extra Info: Brown and red wings with white spots; known for the cracking sound males make with their wings; adults feed on rotting fruit; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests, gardens, and open areas in Central and South America
Extra Info: Black wings with bright red bands; adults feed on nectar and pollen; participates in Müllerian mimicry with other Heliconius species; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Woodlands, forest edges, and gardens across eastern North America
Extra Info: Iridescent blue-black wings with red-orange spots; adults feed on nectar, tree sap, and rotting fruit; caterpillars feed on wild cherry and other trees; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Deciduous forests and woodlands across eastern North America
Extra Info: Pink and yellow wings; adults do not feed; caterpillars feed on maple trees; belongs to the Saturniidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia)
Habitat/Location: Open woodlands, orchards, and gardens in temperate regions of Europe and western Asia
Extra Info: Cream-colored wings with black tiger-like stripes and long tails on hindwings; adults feed on nectar; fast and agile flier; belongs to the Papilionidae family.

Habitat/Location: Open woodlands, gardens, fields, and roadsides across North America
Extra Info: Brown wings with distinctive silver spots on the underside; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on legume plants; belongs to the Hesperiidae family.

Habitat/Location: Grasslands, meadows, and open areas across Europe
Extra Info: Metallic blue-green wings with six red spots; toxic to predators; adults feed on nectar; belongs to the Zygaenidae family.

Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, and gardens across North America
Extra Info: Bright orange wings with black borders; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on legume plants; belongs to the Pieridae family.

Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, roadsides, and gardens across North America
Extra Info: Dark brown to black wings with small white spots; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on mallow and related plants; belongs to the Hesperiidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to North and Central America)
Habitat/Location: Open fields, meadows, roadsides, and gardens in southern United States and Central America
Extra Info: Yellow wings with black “dogface” pattern on the forewings; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on legume plants; belongs to the Pieridae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests and open areas in Central and South America
Extra Info: Brown wings with creamy white stripes; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on dogbane and related plants; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests, woodland edges, and gardens in Central and South America
Extra Info: Brown wings with leaf-like underside; adults feed on rotting fruit and tree sap; larvae feed on Croton species; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical forests and edges in Central and South America
Extra Info: Dark brown wings with two distinct white bars; adults feed on nectar; larvae feed on legume plants; belongs to the Hesperiidae family.

Habitat/Location: Rainforests, gardens, and woodland edges in northeastern Australia, Papua New Guinea, and surrounding islands
Extra Info: Iridescent bright blue wings with black edges; adults feed on nectar; strong flier; belongs to the Papilionidae family

Habitat/Location: Wetlands, fields, meadows, and forest edges across North America
Extra Info: Orange and black wings resembling the Monarch; adults feed on nectar and tree sap; larvae feed on willows, poplars, and cottonwoods; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Habitat/Location: Deserts, gardens, fields, and open areas across North America
Extra Info: Gray-brown wings with white stripes and pink hindwings; adults feed on nectar while hovering like a hummingbird; caterpillars feed on a wide variety of plants; belongs to the Sphingidae family.

Habitat/Location: Forests, woodland edges, and shaded meadows across eastern North America
Extra Info: Brown wings with small eyespots; adults feed on nectar and sap; larvae feed on grasses; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.

Exotic or Not: Not Exotic (native to Europe, Asia, and North America)
Habitat/Location: Meadows, gardens, fields, and open areas across temperate regions
Extra Info: Yellow wings with black tiger-like stripes and long tails on hindwings; adults feed on nectar; caterpillars feed on parsley, carrot, and related plants; belongs to the Papilionidae family.

Habitat/Location: Tropical and subtropical forests, gardens, and edges in Central and South America, and southern United States
Extra Info: Black wings with long white stripes; adults feed on nectar and pollen; participates in Müllerian mimicry; caterpillars feed on passionflower vines; belongs to the Nymphalidae family.
